newsitem.title: USA: CBOT wheat ends mostly lower on late sag in soy.
newsitem.headline: CBOT wheat ends mostly lower on late sag in soy.

text.p: A late sag from the day's highs in soybean futures triggered broad-based speculative selling in the neighboring wheat pit and CBOT wheat futures ended mostly lower, traders said.
"Everybody was selling because beans were down 10 cents from their highs," a trader said.
But wheat was boosted in early dealings by a surge in the CBOT soy complex, which was buoyed by a downward correction by USDA in its estimate for March 1 U.S. soybean stocks.
Wheat also was hit by rumblings in the export market, including persistent talk India was no longer in the market for wheat.

The wheat market was weakened late Monday on talk India over the weekend cancelled a tender for 500,000 tonnes of optional-origin wheat. Overall good crop conditions in U.S. winter wheat areas also checked gains.
Sources this week said very little soft red winter wheat was damaged by floods in Ohio and U.S. Great Plains hard red winter wheat was said in overall good condition.
Wheat closed 3-3/4 cents per bushel lower to four higher, with May down 3-3/4 at $3.93-3/4 a bushel.
